doc.after: As of 2009Â recreational opportunities within the 5-acre (2.0Â ha) Upper Pine Bottom State Park were limited to picknicking and fishing.[2] Although the park was established in the early 1920s as a campground with a latrine,[12] the park today has no campsites or sanitary facilities.[38] Upper Pine Bottom Run was listed in a guide for trout and bass fishing in 1885,[53] and in 1925Â the Department of Forests and Waters said there was good fishing and hunting in the camp. Brown trout over 20 inches (51Â cm) long were reported in the stream in 1994.[51] In 2009, all of Upper Pine Bottom Run has been designated as approved trout waters by the Pennsylvania Fish and Boat Commission, which means that it is stocked with trout and may be fished during trout season.[54]
